{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485826,"name":"blturner","username":"blturner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blturner/{size}/70462_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T18:15:00.780Z","cooked":"

We should get our new Krakens in a few weeks. Our Falcons are on last year’s robot that we need to keep rolling so we can work on vision. We have Neos available to work with on this year’s bot till the Krakens show up.

As I understand it the Falcons and Krakens work best with CTR’s libraries, but if I want to use the Neos and transition to the Krakens we would need to use a generic library and might face a lot of rewriting if we wanted to change libraries mid season.

My best programmer graduated so I want to avoid throwing curveballs at my new programmers as it would all just fall onto me and I have a lot of new kids in mechanical that need me to train them.

My current plan is to do all coding on last year’s bot with CTR libraries till the Krakens show up. Of course that has risk as the Krakens might be too late and this year’s bot will be a paperweight. The other option is to swap motors and controllers twice. move the falcons to this years bot then install the Krakens when they show up.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T18:15:00.780Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":115.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482310,"topic_slug":"programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve","display_username":"blturner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16837,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve/482310/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3485846,"name":"Jeffrey Davis","username":"Practicality","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/practicality/{size}/208492_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T18:31:03.904Z","cooked":"

We’re in a similar boat waiting on encoders. We’re going to try working on other components of the robot as long as possible and hold off on swerve.

But I’m confident I can guide the newbie programmers through coding swerve in a day (or overnight). If it was my first year working with swerve and I was a new programmer I would want a couple of weeks to work out all the kinks. Don’t forget to leave enough time to do autos and driver practice after you finish swerve.

I would recommend preparing with last year’s bot, like you said, but set a cut-off date. If the new motors don’t arrive by then give the programming team enough time to make something that works with what you have.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T18:31:03.904Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":244,"readers_count":243,"score":53.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482310,"topic_slug":"programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve","display_username":"Jeffrey Davis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62548,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve/482310/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3485910,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T19:33:25.195Z","cooked":"

If you have Neos on your current drivetrain, I’d just make separate functions to interact with all your motors but keep all the logic within your main classes the same. For example, instead of using the built in .setVoltage() methods, make your own setVoltage() to interact directly with the motor and call that instead in your periodic loop. This will make it easier to swap out code when the time comes to switch to Krakens.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T19:33:25.195Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":175,"readers_count":174,"score":35.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482310,"topic_slug":"programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/programming-tardy-krakens-for-swerve/482310/3","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3486002,"name":"Otto","username":"GreenTomato","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greentomato/{size}/214780_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T21:02:29.976Z","cooked":"

If you have a Pidgeon and Cancoders on your current bot or have access to them and can swap over the Neos to Falcons I would recommend doing so and then generating a CTRE Swerve (that uses CTRE’S Swerve API ) project with Tuner X. It should be pretty painless compared to switching between some custom swerve solution and something else using CTREs api. You can just re characterize your drive train by generating a new project once you get the Krakens in (or just generating a single file with your drive trains characteristics and dropping it in).

For the record - doing the CTRE swerve drive generator takes maybe like 30 minutes. Maybe more if you have to update and change CAN IDs

I cannot recommend highly enough the swerve tutorials from FIRSTinMichigan regarding the CTRE swerve drive generator. They are fantastic and really walk you through all the steps. My first time swerve students were able to get ours running in a matter of hours.

2025 VRS Swerve Drive Playlist

Practicality:

I would recommend preparing with last year’s bot, like you said, but set a cut-off date. If the new motors don’t arrive by then give the programming team enough time to make something that works with what you have.

So stick with all CTRE and make a deadline. Either the Krakens show or we cannibalize the Falcons on that date.

What encoders and gyro do you have? To use CTRE swerve gen you will need a pigeon 2 and CANCoders.

I also recommend the CTRE swerve gen if possible.

Can you just build competition bot on a new frame and add the swerve drives last when the krakens arrive. I would time your hard cutover around the mechanical progress
